title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.7.55-58 | 26-01-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: This session will be discussing from the last portion of the seventh chapter of the first canto of Bhagavatam.
segments.summary: The lecture begins with prayers and an introduction to the verses from Srimad Bhagavatam that will be discussed.

segments.key_quote: A devotee like Arjuna is able to take help of his intelligence because he is Krishna conscious.
segments.summary: The speaker explains how Arjuna used his intelligence, guided by Krishna consciousness, to resolve a complex situation involving Ashwatthama, highlighting the importance of Krishna's direction.

segments.key_quote: The Supreme Lord as Paramatma directs the intelligence according to our desires according to our karma and according to our position whether we are devotee or non-devotee.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on how Paramatma (Krishna as the Supersoul) guides intelligence based on an individual's desires, karma, and whether they are a devotee or not, explaining how even good intentions can be thwarted by past karma.

segments.key_quote: Therefore the real way to ensure that we always do the right things and never do any sinful activity, never commit any mistake in our life, is to become completely Krishna conscious.
segments.summary: The speaker continues to explain how Paramatma considers desire and karma according to the laws of nature, emphasizing that becoming fully Krishna conscious is the only way to ensure righteous actions and avoid mistakes due to our tiny, influenceable nature.

segments.key_quote: If you want to do the right things, you should actually rise above the gunas.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the influence of the illusory energy and the three modes of nature (gunas) on our actions, stating that to consistently do the right thing, one must rise above these gunas by engaging in pure devotional service, referencing the Bhagavad Gita.

segments.key_quote: Arjuna did not kill him but at the same time he cut his hair from his head deprived him of his wealth his jewel was taken away and driving him from his residence he was driven out of the of the camp so these are prescribed punishments and Arjuna gave those proper punishments
segments.summary: The speaker concludes the discussion of the verses by explaining how Arjuna's actions towards Ashwatthama fulfilled both Draupadi's request and Bhima's suggestion, representing a proper punishment according to scripture, and ends with the Pandavas performing rituals for the dead, marking the end of the chapter.
